resources.string: Address of the place, up to 2 lines
Museum on the Bygdøy peninsula with the world\'s best-preserved Viking ships and finds from Viking tombs around the Oslo Fjord.
The Oslo Opera House is the home of The Norwegian National Opera and Ballet, and the national opera theatre in Norway.
Norsk Folkemuseum, at Bygdøy, Oslo, Norway, is a museum of cultural history with extensive collections of artifacts from all social groups and all regions of the country.

One of the world's oldest and largest open-air museums, with 155 traditional houses from all parts of Norway and a stave church from the year 1200. 
The museum also has indoor exhibits with traditional handicraft items, folk costumes, Sami culture, weapons, toys, pharmaceutical history and changing exhibitions. 
In summer the open-air museum offers freshly-baked lefse, horse and carriage rides, feeding of the animals, guided tours, handicraft demonstrations and much more. 
Norwegian name: Norsk Folkemuseum
Munch Museum is an art museum in Oslo, Norway dedicated to the life and works of the Norwegian artist Edvard Munch.
The Fram Museum is a museum telling the story of Norwegian polar exploration. It is located on the peninsula of Bygdøy in Oslo, Norway.
Holmenkollen Ski Museum is located at the base of the Holmenkollen ski jump in Oslo, Norway. It was founded in 1923 and is the world\'s oldest ski museum.
Holmenkollen National Ski Arena is one of Norway\'s most visited tourist attractions, and includes the Holmenkollen Ski Museum & Jump Tower, shops, a café and a ski simulator.
The Kon-Tiki Museum houses vessels and maps from the Kon-Tiki expedition, as well as a library with about 8000 books.

The Astrup Fearnley Museum of Modern Art is a privately owned contemporary art gallery in Oslo in Norway. The Astrup Fearnley Collection is a collection of modern and contemporary art counted among the most significant of its kind in Northern Europe.

Norway\'s largest public collection of paintings, drawings and sculptures is found in the National Gallery. The gallery\'s central attractions include Edvard Munch\'s The Scream and Madonna, and paintings by Cézanne and Manet.
Sculpture museum located in the studio and home of sculptor Gustav Vigeland (1869-1943). The building is regarded as one of the finest examples of neo-classical architecture in Norway.
Nobel Peace Prize museum with an exciting combination of changing and permanent exhibitions that promote popular interest in issues relating to war, peace and conflict resolution.
The ground floor is home to large collections from the Middle Ages, gold and silver treasures, a permanent exhibition about the Viking Age and the interdisciplinary exhibition Collapse.
The Ibsen Museum includes a comprehensive exhibit featuring the playwright Ibsen\'s life and work, as well as Ibsen\'s private home, where he spent the last 11 years of his life.

Museum of modern and contemporary art at Høvikodden, 15 minutes west of Oslo. Henie Onstad opened in 1968 and was made possible by a generous donation from art collectors Sonja Henie and Niels Onstad.
Museum at Akershus Fortress that documents Norway\'s domestic World War II history from the years 1940-1945.

National museum for technology, industry, science and medicine - a paradise for curious people of all ages. The museum has more than 80 interactive installations and an exciting activity programme during weekends and holidays.
Contemporary art museum with temporary exhibitions and permanent displays from its own collection of 5,000 works by Norwegian and international artists.
The largest park in central parts of Oslo and a popular recreational area for people from all over the city. Inside the park you find Vigeland Sculpture Park, one of Oslo\'s most popular attractions.

Akershus Fortress is a great place to discover Oslo\'s history and enjoy a summer day. The medieval castle, which was completed in the 1300s, had a strategical location at the very end of the headland, and withstood a number of sieges throughout the ages.
Oslo Rådhus. Inaugurated in 1950, Oslo City Hall is the city\'s administrative body and the seat of the City Council.
The royal residence at the top of Karl Johans gate, home to HM King Harald V and HM Queen Sonja. The building is in neo-classical style with a facade of stuccoed brick, and was completed in 1849.

Large garden with ample botanical variety and diversity. Most of the area is designed as an Arboretum, with approximately 1800 different plants. The garden holds a large and varied collection of trees and shrubs planted in a systematic fashion after plant family.

Indoor zoo in the centre of Oslo with more than 100 animals, including boa constrictors, grass snakes, geckos, chameleons, lizards, a poison dart frog, tarantellas, a dwarf crocodile, monkeys, turtles and fish – and a black widow, the world\'s most poisonous spider.
Norway\'s largest amusement park, with more than 30 fun attractions and lots of great games, shops and places to eat.
Sculpture and national heritage park with a strong international art collection surrounded by beautiful scenery with many spectacular lookout points.
Sculpture park located by the Astrup Fearnley Museum at Tjuvholmen. Both were designed by world-renowned architect Renzo Piano.
The largest ski resort in the Oslo area, with 18 slopes and 11 lifts - just 30 minutes from the city centre.

One of Scandinavia\'s largest climbing parks - just 30 minutes from the city centre. Oslo Summer Park is divided into nine trails with varying degrees of difficulty. There are over 150 elements in the park, which also includes 900 metres of zip-lines.
The island closest to the city centre, with beautiful forests, beaches and cultural heritage. North on the island you can visit the ruins of a Cistercian monastery from 1147.
Grefsenkollen is a peak in the northeast of Oslo offering spectacular views of the city. Once at the top, take a walk down to Trollvann lake to fully escape into nature.
Vettakollen is a peak between Holmenkollen and Sognsvann that offers some of the best views you can get overlooking Oslo, the fjord and Holmenkollen.
The Parliament building, seat of the Norwegian National Assembly since 1866.

Lookout tower at Tjuvholmen with a glass elevator. The tower is 54 metres high, and is open to the public in the summer season. From the vantage point you can see the city, the bay, boats and hills from a whole new angle.

The Oslo Pass gives you free entry to more than 30 museums and attractions, free travel on all public transport, free entry to outdoor swimming pools, free walking tours, discounts on sightseeing, ski simulator, Tusenfryd Amusement Park, concert tickets, climbing, ski rental, and special offers in restaurants, shops, entertainment and leisure venues. \nLearn more here.

Oslo’s markets offer food produce, handicrafts and bric-a-brac. Stores in Oslo’s main shopping districts, including upscale Bogstadveien and Karl Johans gate, open 10 AM - 6 PM Monday - Saturday, while malls remain open until 8 PM.

Drinks with an alcohol content higher than 4.6% are only sold at government-owned Vinmonopolet outlets, which close at 6PM Monday-Friday and 3PM Saturdays.

Sales tax (VAT) is 25% and included in the price displayed. Non-Scandinavian residents can claim a tax refund by asking for a tax-free and submitting it at the airport refund desk when leaving the country.

Emergency telephones 

Fire, accidents and serious pollution: Tel 110 
Police - immediate assistance: Tel 112 
Ambulance and Medical assistance: Tel 113
